name: Porcupine Meatballs
description: These easy and flavorful Porcupine Meatballs are made with ground beef and rice, then simmered in a savory tomato sauce.
recipeIngredient: 1/2 cup long grain white rice, uncooked ($0.15)

recipeInstructions.text: In a small bowl, stir together the Italian seasoning, onion powder, garlic powder, salt, and black pepper.
recipeInstructions.name: In a small bowl, stir together the Italian seasoning, onion powder, garlic powder, salt, and black pepper.

recipeInstructions.text: Rinse the rice in cool water and drain well. Add the lean ground beef to a large bowl along with the rice, finely diced onion, minced garlic, egg, and the seasoning mixture.
recipeInstructions.name: Rinse the rice in cool water and drain well. Add the lean ground beef to a large bowl along with the rice, finely diced onion, minced garlic, egg, and the seasoning mixture.

recipeInstructions.text: Use your hands to mix everything together until evenly combined. Try not to overmix as this can make the meatballs tough.
recipeInstructions.name: Use your hands to mix everything together until evenly combined. Try not to overmix as this can make the meatballs tough.

recipeInstructions.text: Divide and shape the meat mixture into 24 meatballs, about two tablespoons each. Place the shaped meatballs into a large pot or dutch oven. It’s ok if the meatballs are touching each other. I also stacked a few on top of each other.
recipeInstructions.name: Divide and shape the meat mixture into 24 meatballs, about two tablespoons each. Place the shaped meatballs into a large pot or dutch oven. It’s ok if the meatballs are touching each other. I also stacked a few on top of each other.

recipeInstructions.text: Now make the sauce. In a medium bowl combine the tomato sauce, crushed tomatoes, Worcestershire sauce, sugar, black pepper, garlic powder, and water. Mix all the ingredients together until well combined. Pour the tomato sauce mixture over the meatballs.
recipeInstructions.name: Now make the sauce. In a medium bowl combine the tomato sauce, crushed tomatoes, Worcestershire sauce, sugar, black pepper, garlic powder, and water. Mix all the ingredients together until well combined. Pour the tomato sauce mixture over the meatballs.

recipeInstructions.text: Cover the pot with a lid and bring the pot to a low boil. Once boiling, turn the heat down to medium-low and let the meatballs simmer for 35-40 minutes.
recipeInstructions.name: Cover the pot with a lid and bring the pot to a low boil. Once boiling, turn the heat down to medium-low and let the meatballs simmer for 35-40 minutes.

recipeInstructions.text: Serve over rice or mashed potatoes with fresh chopped parsley on top and enjoy!
recipeInstructions.name: Serve over rice or mashed potatoes with fresh chopped parsley on top and enjoy!

review.reviewBody: Very good!  I misplaced my regular recipe for Porcupine Balls and I did a Google search and found this recipe.  It's a bit different from mine, but I enjoyed them just the same.  I served them over rice and had green beans on the side.  I would make them again.  The only difference I made was to put the parsley into the meat mixture.
Could I make these in all you can eat cabbage soup?  I love porcupine meatballs, thank you!
This was so easy. Loved by the entire family.

It's a nice recipe, I just wanted to leave comment asking if you drain the crushed tomatoes or not (I left it undrained, which seemed to be alright)

Also, is it possible to offer tsp measurement of the minced garlic. I'm not sure if my cooking has the intended amount of garlic, I think it's maybe a bit too strong in mine, so it's either because my garlic cloves were bigger than yours or I miscalculated when altering the serving sizes. But I think a precise garlic measurement would help greatly!

And it was my first time making meatballs, I didn't press them together hard enough so they fell apart. So tip for fellow meatball novices is compress them with a bit of force 

Also I wonder if somebody can buy store bought tomato sauce if they want to save some time and dishes. Well, I'm sure that's possible but it would be interesting to compare the flavor.

Thanks for the recipe! It was fairly easy. Hardest part for me is cleaning up!

These were excellent, very easy to make and a hit with my family. I had pretty much everything already at home and it provided us with 3 large bowls and leftovers! It is being added into our regular dinner rotation. I really appreciate the gluten free recipes, they tend to be costly but this was simple, quick and affordable.

Hi Marsha--I'm surprised you hadn't yet encountered this Depression era recipe designed to stretch meat, although the recipe is actually much older. Early versions often used condensed tomato soup which has been around, believe it or not, since the 1890s. My mom made porcupine balls once in a while as a memory from her own childhood--using tomato soup as the cooking sauce. Mostly we ate them at my grandmother's house during the 1950s. They are guaranteed kid pleasers, as my own now grown children can attest. I love your updated seasonings for both the meatballs and the sauce--few midwesterners cooked with garlic in the 40s and 50s and now few of us would ever leave it out. Thanks, Marsha--I always look forward to your taste pleasing home style recipes!
